summary: Background Anatid herpesvirus 1 (AHV-1) is an alphaherpesvirus associated with latent infection and mortality in ducks and geese. it is currently affecting the world-wide waterfowl production severely. a fluorescent quantitative real-time PCR (FQ-PCR) method was developed for fast measurement of AHV-1 DNA based on TaqMan MGB technology. AHV-1 is grouped in the alphaherpesviridae subfamily of the herpesvirus family. the viral genome is a linear, double-stranded DNA molecule approximately 180 kb in size. it is the highest reported for any avian herpesvirus in the alphaherpesviridae. TaqMan MGB probe contains a quencher dye that does not emit fluorescence within the detectable wavelength range. a TaqMan MGB-based real-time PCR method for detection and quantitation of AHV-1 is developed to serve as an alternative and improvement of the previously developed ordinary TaqMan real-time PCR method. standard curve of the AHV-1 fluorescent quantitative real-time PCR. dilutions of standard DNA ranging from 1.0 109 to 1.0 102 copies/L were used. the correlation coefficient and the slope value of the regression curve were calculated and are indicated. the results showed that the established FQ-PCR method was characterized by a wide dynamic range (8 logarithmic decades) of detection from 1.0 109 to 1.0 102 pAHV-1 plasmid copies/L with high precision. however, at lower and revealing merely the presence or absence of AHV-1 pathogen have been developed. however, the conventional PCR assays are not sufficient in a variety of clinical situations. they frequently encountered problems including the risk of cross-contamination (leading to false positives) and poor quality of extracts (leading to false negatives) the established AHV-1 detection method is more sensitive and reliable. it was able to detect as few as 1.0 101 DNA copies of template. the high quality hot start Taq DNA polymerase could minimize unspecific amplifications and increase the PCR cycling efficiency. the AHV-1 assay was highly reproducible and linear over a range of eight orders of magnitude from 102 to 109 copies. the results for intra- and inter-assay precision indicate that both intra-assay and inter-assay CVs were satisfactorily low and the assay is reproducible. the method described in this study is especially helpful for high throughput analysis such as evaluating the
